worklogs.comment:
xuechendi commented on pull request #5825: ARROW-7165: [C++] passing memory table to hash functions
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5825
 
 
   This PR is to propose some ideas to support groupby in arrow compute.
   In [JIRA 7165](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-7165), I summarized some steps in my opinion which is required to support groupby.
   1. change functions in arrow/compute/hash to support a input memo_table.(In this PR)
   2. add splitarray function to use dict encode array as input to split current array. I know we have "take", split is quite like "take", while produces multiple array as output.(in comming PR, codes are done)
   So I hope I can get some input here, to see if this is a right path, or you guys already have another plan.
   =================
   In this PR, I moved memo_table from inside RegularHashKernelImpl class member to the API function, so user can either pass memo_table or init memo_table there.
   
   Signed-off-by: Chendi Xue <chendi.xue@intel.com>
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

   I'm a bit hesitant to express views one way or another without seeing an implementation of a hash aggregation fully worked out. Does that make sense?

xuechendi commented on issue #5825: ARROW-7165: [C++] passing memory table to hash functions
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5825#issuecomment-557338536
 
 
   > I'm a bit hesitant to express views one way or another without seeing an implementation of a hash aggregation fully worked out. Does that make sense?
   
   I see, my current "group by hash aggregation" is a combination of "encode dict" + "splitarray" + "aggregate", hope below graph can make my design more clear, after getting a encodedArray from the grouping column, we can use that encodedArray to split all arrays in one batch and then perform aggregate to each array. 
   ![groupby_hash_aggregate](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4355494/69388528-131e3b00-0d04-11ea-83a1-349eab5899cb.png)
   and we can use one hash_table(memo_table) for multiple batches so data within same group from different batches can be splitted into same array.
   I have completed all codes in my side, while I felt it will be a ton of effort to fix the naming convention for arrow, so I hope I can get some input firstly of knowing if you want to see such an implementation? 
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

wesm commented on issue #5825: ARROW-7165: [C++] passing memory table to hash functions
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5825#issuecomment-557849661
 
 
   In general, I am not in favor of "speculative" refactoring. Since there are no unit tests in this patch, that's how this seems to me. I think we need to take a step back and have a broader discussion about the implementation strategy for hash aggregations and other grouping algortihms. Once a strategy has been agreed upon, I do not think we should be accepting any patch until a meaningful algorithm (and associated unit tests) have been implemented. 
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

xuechendi commented on issue #5825: ARROW-7165: [C++] passing memory table to hash functions

   > In general, I am not in favor of "speculative" refactoring. Since there are no unit tests in this patch, that's how this seems to me. I think we need to take a step back and have a broader discussion about the implementation strategy for hash aggregations and other grouping algortihms. Once a strategy has been agreed upon, I do not think we should be accepting any patch until a meaningful algorithm (and associated unit tests) have been implemented.
   
   I see, thanks, @wesm , is there a development discussion meeting we can attend to propose our idea of groupby hash aggregation, or we simply submit design doc on JIRA so anyone interested will comment on that? Which is a prefer way?

issuetype.description: A new feature of the product, which has yet to be developed.
issuetype.name: New Feature

fields.description:
Not sure if there is any plan to support groupby in arrow?

Here is some to do in my mind:
 # To make current arrow/compute/kernels/hash supporting received a memo_table as input, so multiple array will be able to get dictencode and valuecount based on same hashmap with a unified index.
 # To add a split array function instead of using take multiple time to split one array to several ones.
 # so the output array can use current funcs under compute/kernels, such as sum/count/sort to support group by.

But this is some of my basic idea, wanna know if there is a on going plan on this?

comments.body: I think this is a duplicate of https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-5002
